sec.title: Origins of activities and strength of contextual links
sec.p: Earlier arguments for evidence of embeddedness included examples in which the contextual links or coordination mechanisms were preserved by the firm or easily accessible. If we apply this idea to activities that were internally developed versus acquired, then I expect retention to be greater for internally developed activities than for those acquired due to the familiarity with contextual links formed around internal activities. Of the 1274 unique product market activities in the full sample, 815 were internally developed, 443 were acquired, and 16 were joint ventures. On average, retention was 81% for internally developed activities and 56% for acquired activities. These descriptive statistics provide initial support for Hypothesis 4 that predicts that internally developed activities are more likely to be retained than those that are acquired.

For a more accurate test, I add this independent variable to the earlier models from Table 4 to analyze the effect of activity ‘origin type’ on likelihood of retention. Table 5 reports the models’ results of the activity retention analysis. In Model 15 the independent variable is a dummy for market activity origin type (‘PM origin type’, where acquired activities are coded as 1). Model 16 adds the prior relevant independent variable ‘PM’s unit-of-origin retained by firm(t)’, and Model 17 adds the control ‘unit-of-origin A or AA’.

The results in Table 5 for Models 15–16 do not support Hypothesis 4. Recall that ‘PM origin type’ is referring to how the activity came to be established within the organization as either acquired (1) or internally developed (0), whereas ‘unit-of-origin retained(t)’ is referring to whether the unit-of-origin’s context and links exist anywhere within the organization. Strikingly, an activity’s origin type is not a significant factor affecting its retention when controlling for unit-of-origin retention. This indicates that with regards to activity retention, the existence of contextual links (within the firm) is more influential than the familiarity (and source) of those links. Stated differently, what is relevant to value creation is not how the activity came to be (i.e. whether a product market activity is acquired or not), but how the activity is organized (i.e. whether the coordination mechanisms associated with that activity are retained by the organization).

sec.title: Exploring unit-level contextual links within the context of the firm
sec.p: The study of activity origin type inferred, based on past studies, that firms are more familiar with the activity-level contextual links underlying internally developed activities than acquired activities. Other than the test of Hypothesis 4 which revealed that there is a superseding influence of having accessible the unit-of-origin context, the descriptive statistics still highlight that acquired activities are retained less often than internally developed ones. This provides some support for the concept of activity embeddedness and that preservation of contextual links provides value to the firm as indicated by activity retention.

Just as activities may be embedded within their business unit contexts, an analogous comparison may be made of business units being embedded within their firm contexts. The greater the impact of a firm’s coordination mechanisms on the value creation by a unit, the greater its ‘unit embeddedness’. If activity origin type has an influence on retention and indicates possible evidence of activity-level contextual links, then unit origin type may also provide evidence of unit-level contextual links if unit origin has an impact on unit retention. Similar to what is inferred about activities, I expect that familiarity with unit-level contextual links (i.e. the coordination mechanisms employed by the firm across all of its units) is weaker for acquired units than internally developed units due to the time invested in the latter. In an earlier study of business unit reconfiguration (Karim, 2006), I found that acquired units were in fact retained for a shorter duration than internally developed units. In that paper, the hazard of ‘not being retained’ diminished over time for acquired units; the finding supports the idea that these targets’ unit-level contextual links are either eventually better understood by the new parent organization or better understood because the routines and processes of the parent firm eventually permeate and integrate the acquired unit further into the firm’s context.

To test the joint influence of both activity-level and unit-level contextual links on activity retention, Model 17 of Table 5 includes the additional variable ‘unit-of-origin A or AA’, which represents the origin type of an activity’s unit-of-origin. If the unit that is responsible for an activity (regardless of whether this activity was internally developed by this unit post-acquisition or if this activity was acquired as part of this unit) was an acquisition or a recombination of several targets (i.e. an ‘A or AA’ unit), then the parent firm will likely have less familiarity with the unit-level contextual links between this unit and the firm versus those units-of-origin that are internally developed. Interestingly, Model 17 reveals that this added control is insignificant, implying that activity-level contextual links (binding activities to their unit context) may be more influential than unit-level contextual links (binding units to the firm context) when it comes to creating value from activities.

sec.title: Discussion and conclusion
sec.p: The goal of this study was to explore the concept of structural embeddedness – the extent to which the contextual environment (with its coordination mechanisms, routines, and processes) affects value creation from a market activity. Because the detailed study of multiple market activities within business units is still relatively new in the field of organization design, one motivation for this article was to define constructs that made the distinction between (multiple) activities within the context of their units versus (multiple) units within the context of their firms. Another goal was to question why and how this context may matter. Drawing on classic organizational design literature, I discussed how coordination mechanisms that have been examined by scholars and applied to the firm with respect to its units may also be applied to a business unit with respect to its market activities. Finally, to explore whether the retention of activities’ contextual environments (with their contextual links) is impactful to value creation, I empirically examined how changes in the structural context around the activities impact the future retention of the activity. I argue that finding significant impact is some indication of structural embeddedness.

Changes in the structural context around activities were examined from several dimensions. The article explores the concept of activity-level contextual links by studying the retention of activities that experienced linked versus unlinked movements, that were moved versus not moved, that kept versus lost their unit-of-origin context, and that were internally developed versus acquired.

Overall, most of the hypotheses in this study are supported, providing some evidence for the concept of significant structural embeddedness of market activities within business units. First, the study’s sample shows that activity reconfiguration usually occurs simultaneously with business unit reconfiguration rather than independently of it. This finding is aligned with the expectation that activities become embedded within their unit context and develop activity-level contextual links as coordination mechanisms are developed to bring these market activities to fruition. It is less common for activities to be moved between units (while both the units maintain their boundaries) and, instead, it is more often the case that activities are moved by recombining units. It should be acknowledged, however, that the movement of activities independently of any unit movement does still occur, as observed by the sample of 149 unlinked activity movements in this study and the examples of unlinked activity movements discussed in earlier papers (Galunic and Eisenhardt, 1996, 2001). The tradeoff between preserving and destroying activity-level contextual links may be driven by necessity; the dynamic capabilities perspective supports independent activity movements for those businesses in turbulent markets where speedy change is required. I find that there is a slightly higher percentage of retention for those activities experiencing linked versus unlinked movements, but the difference is not statistically significant.

Second, market activities facing no movements (i.e. the status quo) are more likely retained than those experiencing either linked or unlinked activity movements. This supports the idea that the activity-level contextual links may be better preserved when there is no disruption of movement, thus leading to greater value creation and retention. Third, most disruptive to the firm are cases where the original unit responsible for an activity is no longer maintained in any manner within the firm; it has been divested or dissolved. Results show that these activities are least likely to be retained by the firm, supporting the idea that the firm no longer has the unit-of-origin from which to learn about the underlying routines and processes that were once associated with an activity. When jointly observing the effects of lack of activity movement and retention of unit-of-origin, the study reveals that what is impacting activity retention is the latter, not the former. This implies that having access or being informed about the coordination mechanisms necessary for effective activity management (i.e. how the activity was reconfigured) may be more relevant than whether the activity was reconfigured. This has some strong implications for how knowledge is managed within organizations. If we consider one instrument of knowledge to be key personnel, the organization may still effectively reap the knowledge from this individual if he or she is moved within the organization as long as the individual is retained somewhere within the firm such that he or she can still be accessed. Recall that prior work has shown that knowledge may be embedded both in individuals and in their social arrangements (Hansen, 1999; Szulanski, 1996). If we make the analogy of comparing these social arrangements to the coordination mechanisms linking activities to units, then the findings here imply that the preservation of the social arrangement somewhere within the firm (even if it is moved within) may be what is more influential in creating value from the knowledge than whether or not an individual was moved within the firm. This implication would advocate keeping teams that work well together and have strong social ties intact as they are moved or reapplied within the firm.

Fourth, whereas Hypotheses 1, 2, and 3 focused on the existence of activity-level contextual links, Hypothesis 4 studied the potential familiarity with these contextual links. I find that acquired activities are less likely to be retained than internally developed activities. This supports the idea that lack of preserving contextual links (in the case of acquisitions) may lead to less value creation. When comparing the effects of activity origin type and the removal of an activity’s unit-of-origin, the study reveals that having or not having contextual links (i.e. the unit-of-origin’s context is either somewhere within the firm or it is not) is far more influential than the degree of familiarity with those links (as internally developed or acquired). This has significant implications to acquisition research as many acquisitions are broken up – some activities or assets may be retained while others are not; ultimately some parts are usually shut down or divested (Porter, 1987). Based on the findings here, I question whether some acquisitions that have been deemed failures could have been value creating if they had been reconfigured in such a way as to retain activity-level contextual links within the firm – even while other pieces of the acquisition were divested. Thus, what is relevant is not whether an activity or asset was acquired or internally developed so much as what was done with its original context.

Finally, this study explores the analogous concept of unit-level contextual links that are coordination mechanisms employed by the firm across all of its business units. In an earlier paper (Karim, 2006), I found that internally developed units are retained for a longer duration than acquired units, supporting this study’s logic of expecting stronger unit embeddedness within the firm for internally developed units. Adding this information about the origin type of an activity’s unit-of-origin reveals that activity-level contextual links (that bind an activity to its unit context) are more influential than unit-level contextual links (that bind a unit to its firm context) in determining activity retention. There may be several interpretations of this finding. Recall that the firm-specific coordination mechanisms applied by a firm across all of its units – its unit-level contextual links or what Mintzberg (1979) referred to as ‘lateral linkages’ – must be more generic by definition and applicative across many diversified units. Activity-level contextual links, on the other hand, are more specific to the nuances of the markets within each unit – that which links them together to have been grouped in the first place. These coordination mechanisms will likely differ from unit to unit within a firm, based on the activities within each unit. In this regard, I expect the design of business units to be more diversified as their groupings of market activities are more distinct. Because the firm-specific coordination mechanisms are more generic, it may be that their dissemination across units is more successful (regardless of whether they are applied to internally developed units or to acquired units) than a firm trying to reinvent unit-specific activity-level contextual links once the unit-of-origin is removed (again, regardless of whether the activity was internally developed or acquired). A counter-argument may be that though lateral linkages may be generic, they may still be quite sophisticated – take for example the logistical operations of Wal-Mart. However, though they may be sophisticated, the repeated application of these coordination mechanisms across all business units (both internally developed ones and acquired ones) likely makes the firm improve upon this process over time – similar to the diffusion of best practices throughout an organization. In contrast, there may be limited carry-over of activity-level contextual links that can be applied across units. Thus, the implications of the above finding suggest that firms should value the specifics of units’ coordination mechanisms as applied to their market activities – these may not be as readily reproduced as firms’ lateral linkages.

The main implication of this study is that when referring to organizations that are reconfiguring their activities, scholars and practitioners should acknowledge the unit structures within which these activities reside. From a dynamic capabilities perspective, as firms alter their divisional responsibilities and move activities from one unit to another, managers should consider whether they will reap their optimal value without the coordination mechanisms that were unit-specific for this activity. Based on the findings of this study, I would recommend to executives to move activities in conjunction with unit recombination. As another example, consider firms modularizing their product architectures such that activities may be partitioned into new arrangements. In such instances, firms should consider whether these new arrangements are preserving or destroying contextual links that may be critical for the activity to be effectively deployed. Another consideration may be the lost opportunities from the lack of movement or modularization of internal activities; if activities become too embedded within their unit contexts such that their coordination mechanisms are non-transferable, this, too may have an opportunity cost from lack of flexibility (in the case of modularization) or lost synergies with other activities (in the case of potentially moving the activity to a new destination unit).

This study has several significant limitations and there remains much room for future study. This is a first attempt at approaching the issue of structural embeddedness. Although the article theorizes about coordination mechanisms that are applied to activities to improve their value creation, it does not actually measure these routines or processes that are unit-specific and activity-nuanced. A subsequent study that could capture different contextual links applied at different units within a diversified firm, and then examine activity movement and retention would be ideal. This article assumes that retention indicates some market activity value to firms. Because most cases of activity movement occurred simultaneously with unit movement, it is inferred that this (preservation of activity-level contextual links) is one way in which firms reap that value (i.e. performance) from their businesses. Unfortunately, the data source did not provide financial data at the activity level, nor at the unit level, but did so only at the firm level. Thus, a future study on retention that could control for product market activities’ financial performance would be beneficial for more granular operationalization of value creation. Further, a study of the performance outcomes of activity movements that are independent of or interdependent with unit movement would also reinforce the expectations about value creation. Finally, although the study uses lagged predictors to limit biases from endogeneity, there is always the possibility of reverse causality – that due to its retention an activity could then be reconfigured. Knowing more about the intent behind both activity retention and movements would benefit future studies.

In conclusion, this study of simultaneous activity and unit reconfiguration provides insight into how firms evolve within the constraints of structural boundaries. Hopefully this article contributes to both practitioners’ and scholars’ better understanding of the process by which firms manage market activities and business units, and provides terminology for future dialogue on structural embeddedness.

The meaning of the term ‘embed’ means (1) (a) to enclose closely in or as if in a matrix, (b) to make something an integral part of, (c) to prepare for sectioning by infiltrating with and enclosing in a supporting substance, and (2) to surround closely (www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/embed; my italics).

I use the terms ‘business unit’ and ‘product market activity’ to remain consistent with both the data source that labeled these constructs in this manner, as well as with previous papers that build upon this line of research, and studies in classic organization design that also use these terms (Mintzberg, 1979).

Extending research on charters, recently Birkinshaw and Lingblad (2005) studied intrafirm competition and charter overlap between business units, and developed a theoretical framework to identify the relationship between units based on the amount of overlap and the fungibility of charter scope.

A review of literature referring to embeddedness reveals several applications and studies, mostly dealing with either social networks or external environments and institutions. Zukin and DiMaggio (1990) identified four types of embeddedness: structural, cognitive, cultural, and political. In the case of structural embeddedness, they are referring to actors being embedded within a social network. This referral to embeddedness within networks is common in sociology literature (Dacin et al., 1999; Granovetter, 1985; McEvily and Marcus, 2005; Moran, 2005). Other applications of ‘embeddedness’ include the study of learning processes and how they are embedded within culture (Barney, 1986; Karnoe, 1995) and in power relations (Contu and Willmott, 2003). Several studies have alluded to embeddedness within a context; examples include institutional forces being embedded in national environments (Yiu and Makino, 2002) and actors’ construction of events being embedded within structural surroundings (Peterson, 1998). Context has also been applied to tacit resources. Volkoff et al. (2007) explore how routines and roles may be embedded in technology. Others have studied how knowledge is embedded within functional practices (Carlile, 2002), and whether knowledge is embedded within individuals, structure, or technology (Argote, 1996).

bio.title: Author biography
bio.p: Samina Karim (PhD, Corporate Strategy, University of Michigan) is Assistant Professor of Strategy and Innovation at Boston University’s School of Management. Samina’s research focuses on structural reconfiguration, creating value from acquisitions, innovation, and strategic change via market entry and exit. Her research has been published in several journals including Strategic Management Journal and Management Science. Samina currently serves on the editorial boards of the Strategic Management Journal and Organization Science, on the Executive Committee for the BPS division of the Academy of Management, and as co-chair for the BPS Doctoral Consortium for 2011 and 2012.
